Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Machine Learning Algorithms and Tools for Analysis and Optimization of Infrastructure
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to develop algorithmic methods and computational systems that will provide new information, cheaply, quickly, consistently, and at a large scale, to inform investments in building, energy, and green infrastructure for engineering consultancies, construction companies, power utilities, real-estate developers, and cities. Currently, studies for built, energy, and green infrastructure investments are typically made case-by-case and employ infrequent, manual, and expensive audits performed by trained professionals. In addition, the ground-truth data (site surveys and other urban asset databases) used to inform these decisions are siloed across stakeholders and are often expensive and difficult to collect. The ecosystem of simulation and analysis tools is fragmented into a variety of highly complex software packages that require considerable effort and customization. This results in much repeated effort, inconsistent results across different projects, and high costs for surveys and instrumentation.

This I-Corps project will investigate commercial applications of a machine learning system that ingests, aggregates, processes and learns mappings between, remote-sensing, model simulation, and local sensor and survey data on buildings and their environment. The data used will be best-available open source and commercial satellite data, as well as Internet of Things data from buildings and energy infrastructure. The project further develops neural-network based generative machine learning models that can emulate complex physical and engineering systems but are much cheaper and faster to deploy and maintain in practice. This system would allow users to make inferences (physical parameter recovery, forecasts) about built, green, and energy infrastructure and their surroundings (micro-climates) where this data is not available, in a low-cost, large-scale, automated way, removing the need for certain expensive sensor deployments or manual surveys. The system develops a top-down, machine-learning based simulation capability that would allow to perform fast scenario and impact analysis of investments and interventions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This I-Corps project explores the commercialization potential of an emerging technology at the intersection of the Artificial Intelligence and environmental science applications space. The intellectual merit of this project includes development of, and understanding of, the commercial opportunities of a physics-enabled Artificial Intelligence climate/weather risk forecasting platform that is accurate, fast, cost-effective, and deployable via cloud computing.

Significant results include the identification of customer segments, the discovery of pivots necessary to target these segments, and the identification of a value proposition for these customer segments. The primary discovered value proposition was in being able to provide accurate, fast and affordable forecasts of climate/weather risk to renewable energy and insurance customers.

The project has provided many opportunities for training and professional development, including the Cat Modeling 2018 Embracing Volatility conference and entrepreneurship training materials. In addition, individual meetings were conducted with stakeholders in the energy, insurance, municipalities, and finance sectors. Companies that the team interviewed included Verbund AG, one of the largest European hydropower owner/operators.

The broader impacts of this work include: 1) dissemination of the learnings, and 2) increased potential for impact in the energy, insurance, municipalities, and finance for more insightful and affordable climate/weather risk estimation tools. The learnings of this I-Corps project have been disseminated through presentations and papers. During the seven-week workshop program, the team executed upwards of 100 customer interviews with stakeholders in several sectors of interest, including energy, insurance, municipalities, and finance.  After the program ended, the team performed an additional 100+ interviews focusing on energy and insurance as main sectors. The team?s involvement in I-Corps and the learning from I-Corps led to the development of a successful pilot project with Verbund, and a successful NSF Phase I SBIR proposal. The NSF SBIR Phase I award then led to the development and validation of proof-of-concept modules of our physics-informed AI platform, on several applications of interest developed with customers: 1) AI-based spatio-temporal emulation tested for hydroclimate modeling (particularly, mountain snowpack) for a hydropower generation forecasting application with Verbund, 2) AI-based downscaling of mesoscale climate models (particularly, wind intensity output of the Weather Research and Forecasting, or WRF, model) for a wind intensity forecasting pilot with the wind power company Renew, and 3) initial work on combining spatio-temporal emulation and downscaling for a fire spread modeling application (using WRF-SFIRE) with Microsoft.

Through I-Corps, the team was able to identify real problems in the renewable energy and insurance markets that could benefit greatly from physics-enabled AI risk forecasting. In particular, the team discovered that current state-of-the-art weather/climate risk forecasting technology is inaccurate, slow, and prohibitively expensive, and ripe for disruptive technology. This was a discovery made through in?person interviews.

From participation in I?Corps, the team has a better understanding of what capabilities should be demonstrated by their technology in order to license to larger companies and/or displace incumbent technologies. The team EL, Adrian Albert, has launched a startup company to incorporate his I-corps learnings and take the physics-enabled AI technology to market.
